SubTopics: Interpret figures of speech (e.g., personification) in context.
Content: In line 3, what does the simile “like clouds across the sky” help the reader understand about the horses in Euphemia's sketches?

A.Choice: They are drawn sloppily.

B.Choice: They look like they are in motion.

C.Choice: They are getting tangled up with each other.

D.Choice: They look like they are trotting through fog.

SubTopics: Analyze how a particular sentence, chapter, scene, or stanza fits into the overall structure of a text and contributes to the development of the theme, setting, or plot.
Content: How do lines 14 through 16 contribute to the development of the plot?

A.Choice: They establish Marisa's problem.

B.Choice: They emphasize Marisa's hopefulness.

C.Choice: They contrast Marisa's artistic abilities with Euphemia's.

D.Choice: They illustrate Marisa's determination to not let Luke bother her.

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative and connotative meanings; analyze the impact of a specific word choice on meaning and tone.
Content: Which phrase best conveys the tone in lines 1 through 30?

A.Choice: “They're always running wild and free ...” (lines 2 and 3)

B.Choice: “He also calls me Messy.” (lines 8 and 9)

C.Choice: “Next I roughed in most of the body ...” (lines 17 and 18)

D.Choice: “I scratched a big X through my earless, macaroni‑legged horse, ...” (line 26)

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative and connotative meanings; analyze the impact of a specific word choice on meaning and tone.
Content: Read this sentence from line 32.
:box:I brooded about it all through dinner.
What effect does the word “brooded” have in the story?

A.Choice: It shows Marisa's anxiety about her abilities.

B.Choice: It reveals Marisa's motives for drawing.

C.Choice: It emphasizes how Marisa is growing as a character.

D.Choice: It indicates Marisa has a major decision to make.

SubTopics: Determine a theme or central idea of a text and how it is conveyed through particular details; provide a summary of the text distinct from personal opinions or judgments.
Content: How do lines 36 through 38 help convey the theme of the story?

A.Choice: They show that some situations take time to change.

B.Choice: They prove that practice can help natural talents to develop.

C.Choice: They suggest that inspiration may come in unexpected ways.

D.Choice: They demonstrate that new ideas will eventually be accepted.

SubTopics: Cite textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: Which sentence best explains why Marisa's final horse drawing was different than her first tries?

A.Choice: “Everything looked special in that light, even the scraggly horses next door.” (lines 37 and 38)

B.Choice: “I noticed the curves of their muscles, the shadows on their faces, the shine along their backs.” (lines 42 through 44)

C.Choice: “An idea began to take shape in my mind, and just then the cinnamon horse turned its head toward me and nodded three times.” (lines 49 and 50)

D.Choice: “I choose a deep brown, pulling it across my paper in the shape of the chocolate horse.” (line 52)

SubTopics: Describe how a particular story's or drama's plot unfolds in a series of episodes as well as how the characters respond or change as the plot moves toward a resolution.
Content: How does Marisa change while watching her neighbors' horses?

A.Choice: She realizes that Euphemia's horses do not look realistic, so she decides to try to draw better pictures than her friend.

B.Choice: She decides to try a different way of drawing and is proud of her work.

C.Choice: She realizes she can never be an artist like Euphemia but wants to draw like her anyway.

D.Choice: She finally learns that drawing horses is easier with proper lighting and art supplies.

SubTopics: Cite textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: Read line 15 of the story.
:box:“You call this one only fair?” he asked. “It is a gem for the king.”
What does this line suggest about the father?

A.Choice: He has not looked at the pearl as closely as Ramón has.

B.Choice: He does not think that Ramón is correct about the pearl.

C.Choice: He is testing Ramón's confidence in judging the pearl's value.

D.Choice: He is teaching Ramón about the pearl's quality.

SubTopics: Cite textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: Which detail from the story best supports the idea that Ramón is becoming an expert at judging pearls?

A.Choice: “'For this one,' he said, 'what is your notation?' ” (lines 11 and 12)

B.Choice: “'For a poor king,' I said.” (line 16)

C.Choice: “'With a little care the flaw can be peeled away,' he said.” (lines 19 and 20)

D.Choice: “I would like to go today.” (line 29)

SubTopics: Cite textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: Why is the father reluctant to bring Ramón on a pearl‑diving trip?

A.Choice: He is concerned for Ramón's safety.

B.Choice: He needs Ramón to evaluate more pearls.

C.Choice: He thinks Ramón is still too young to sail.

D.Choice: He is unsure Ramón is ready to dive.

SubTopics: Describe how a particular story's or drama's plot unfolds in a series of episodes as well as how the characters respond or change as the plot moves toward a resolution.
Content: In line 55, why does Ramón suggest that he will “stay on deck while the others dive”?

A.Choice: His father needs him to help with other jobs on the boat.

B.Choice: He realizes that his father will never actually let him go.

C.Choice: His father has convinced him that it is too dangerous.

D.Choice: He is trying to gradually change his father's mind.

SubTopics: Analyze how a particular sentence, chapter, scene, or stanza fits into the overall structure of a text and contributes to the development of the theme, setting, or plot.
Content: How does line 57 best contribute to the development of the story?

A.Choice: by signaling a turning point

B.Choice: by providing a solution to the problem

C.Choice: by comparing the characters' actions

D.Choice: by introducing a new conflict

SubTopics: Describe how a particular story's or drama's plot unfolds in a series of episodes as well as how the characters respond or change as the plot moves toward a resolution.
Content: How does the father change during the story?

A.Choice: He becomes concerned about a diver's health.

B.Choice: He begins to acknowledge Ramón's maturity.

C.Choice: He becomes frustrated by Ramón's persistence.

D.Choice: He stops worrying about his family business.

SubTopics: Explain how an author develops the point of view of the narrator or speaker in a text.
Content: The author develops Ramón's point of view in the story mostly by

A.Choice: describing Ramón's fear of pearl diving

B.Choice: including Ramón's analysis of the pearl

C.Choice: describing how Ramón feels about his father

D.Choice: including dialogue between Ramón and his father

SubTopics: Analyze in detail how a key individual, event, or idea is introduced, illustrated, and elaborated in a text (e.g., through examples or anecdotes).
Content: In lines 4 through 12, the author explains why scientists are trying to find a way to produce spider silk using goats by showing

A.Choice: possible uses for spider silk

B.Choice: the popularity of spider silk

C.Choice: how easy spider silk is to use

D.Choice: how quickly spider silk can be developed

SubTopics: Cite textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: Which statement best explains an advantage of using goats rather than spiders for the production of silk?

A.Choice: Goats produce stronger silk than spiders do.

B.Choice: Scientists can insert genes into goats but not into spiders.

C.Choice: Spider proteins in goat milk can be spun into silk.

D.Choice: Goats are bigger than spiders and are much easier to raise.

SubTopics: Analyze in detail how a key individual, event, or idea is introduced, illustrated, and elaborated in a text (e.g., through examples or anecdotes).
Content: What did Jeffrey Turner discover about using Nubian goats for possible silk production?

A.Choice: Nubian goats already make a similar substance.

B.Choice: Nubian goats have high amounts of protein in their milk.

C.Choice: Nubian goats and spiders both prefer living in large groups.

D.Choice: Nubian goats and spiders have body parts that are similar.

SubTopics: Analyze in detail how a key individual, event, or idea is introduced, illustrated, and elaborated in a text (e.g., through examples or anecdotes).
Content: In the process described in lines 35 through 47, which step allows the threads to become strong enough for surgical procedures?

A.Choice: The silk proteins are turned into clumps.

B.Choice: The silk is stretched repeatedly.

C.Choice: Salt is added to the goat's milk.

D.Choice: Water is added to thin the clumps.

SubTopics: Analyze how a particular sentence, paragraph, chapter, or section fits into the overall structure of a text and contributes to the development of the ideas.
Content: Why are lines 55 through 59 important to the article?

A.Choice: They suggest that the goats are unusual.

B.Choice: They explain how the goats are kept busy.

C.Choice: They explain that the goats are treated well.

D.Choice: They suggest that the goats are like humans.

SubTopics: Determine a central idea of a text and how it is conveyed through particular details; provide a summary of the text distinct from personal opinions or judgments.
Content: Which statement best expresses a central idea of the article?

A.Choice: Nubian goats produce better quality silk than spiders.

B.Choice: Spider silk is a complex substance that takes effort to make.

C.Choice: Nubian goats have been genetically altered to produce spider silk.

D.Choice: Spider silk contains proteins that are similar to proteins in other living things.

SubTopics: Determine a central idea of a text and how it is conveyed through particular details; provide a summary of the text distinct from personal opinions or judgments.
Content: Which detail is most important to include in a summary of the article?

A.Choice: Scientists have made an attempt to gather silk from spiders living on farms.

B.Choice: Spider silk has qualities that can be used in many products.

C.Choice: A scientist started a company to research goat silk.

D.Choice: Machines spin spider silk into thin threads.

SubTopics: Describe how a particular story's or drama's plot unfolds in a series of episodes as well as how the characters respond or change as the plot moves toward a resolution.
Content: How does Nina's attitude toward Ms. Charlemagne change?

A.Choice: Nina becomes less interested after noticing Ms. Charlemagne's bracelets.

B.Choice: Nina becomes more fascinated after learning Ms. Charlemagne's name.

C.Choice: Nina becomes less surprised after hearing Ms. Charlemagne's viewpoints.

D.Choice: Nina becomes more suspicious after hearing Ms. Charlemagne's assignment.

SubTopics: Analyze how a particular sentence, chapter, scene, or stanza fits into the overall structure of a text and contributes to the development of the theme, setting, or plot.
Content: How do lines 34 through 39 contribute to the development of the story?

A.Choice: by suggesting that Ms. Charlemagne is not qualified to teach art

B.Choice: by introducing Nina to a new way to think about art

C.Choice: by showing that Ms. Charlemagne does not understand how artists work

D.Choice: by describing the way Nina usually completes art assignments

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative and connotative meanings; analyze the impact of a specific word choice on meaning and tone.
Content: Why does the author use the word “chirped” in line 43 of the story?

A.Choice: to reveal that Ms. Charlemagne has creative ideas

B.Choice: to imply that Ms. Charlemagne is new at teaching art

C.Choice: to demonstrate that Ms. Charlemagne has a cheerful outlook

D.Choice: to show that Ms. Charlemagne easily relates to the art students

SubTopics: Analyze how a particular sentence, chapter, scene, or stanza fits into the overall structure of a text and contributes to the development of the theme, setting, or plot.
Content: Read this sentence from line 54.
:box:I could change that number, at least here if not in real life.
How does this sentence best contribute to the development of the story?

A.Choice: by signaling a change in Nina's thinking

B.Choice: by emphasizing the importance of the setting

C.Choice: by revealing Nina's strong feelings

D.Choice: by suggesting a new plot development

SubTopics: Determine a theme or central idea of a text and how it is conveyed through particular details; provide a summary of the text distinct from personal opinions or judgments.
Content: Which quotation best supports a theme of the story?

A.Choice: “Still, I knew she liked the picture and felt proud to see it up on the wall.” (lines 8 and 9)

B.Choice: “I had never seen anything like them.” (line 18)

C.Choice: “Imagine being descended from a medieval French king!” (lines 30 and 31)

D.Choice: “I was the lord of my own picture, wasn't I?” (line 56)

SubTopics: Cite textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Content: Based on details in the story, what can readers conclude about Ms. Charlemagne?

A.Choice: She is a respected artist.

B.Choice: She has a famous relative.

C.Choice: She has a unique personality.

D.Choice: She is a popular substitute teacher.

SubTopics: Determine a theme or central idea of a text and how it is conveyed through particular details; provide a summary of the text distinct from personal opinions or judgments.
Content: How do the details in the story help develop a theme?

A.Choice: Nina's thoughts about her mother help develop the theme that being honest will make you feel better.

B.Choice: Nina's interaction with Isobel helps develop the theme that experiencing a new situation is easier with a friend.

C.Choice: Nina's drawing helps develop the theme that expressing yourself can help you work through your struggles.

D.Choice: Nina's description of Ms. Charlemagne helps develop the theme that judging others by their appearance is not a good idea.

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative, connotative, and technical meanings.
Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English grammar and usage when writing or speaking.
Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English capitalization, punctuation, and spelling when writing.
Content: What is the meaning of the word “contradicts” as it is used in line 24 of the article? Use two details from the article to support your response.

SubTopics: Analyze how a particular sentence, paragraph, chapter, or section fits into the overall structure of a text and contributes to the development of the ideas.
Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English grammar and usage when writing or speaking.
Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English capitalization, punctuation, and spelling when writing.
Content: How do lines 25 and 26 contribute to the development of a key idea in the article “ 'Ideas That Work ... and Those That Don't' from When is a Planet Not a Planet? The Story of Pluto ”? Use two details from the article to support your response.

SubTopics: Determine an author's point of view or purpose in a text and explain how it is conveyed in the text.
Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English grammar and usage when writing or speaking.
Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English capitalization, punctuation, and spelling when writing.
Use knowledge of language and its conventions when writing, speaking, reading, or listening.
Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases based on grade 6 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies.
Content: Why does the author compare how people treat “pets” and “pests” in the article? How does the author develop ways that people are helping “pests” throughout the article? Use details from the article to support your response.

:box:In your response, be sure to

• explain why the author compares how people treat “pets” and “pests” in the article
• explain how the author develops ways that people are helping “pests” throughout the article
• use details from the article to support your response

Content: How does the reunion affect Paolo's parents and Benjamin? Use two details from the story to support your response.

Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English grammar and usage when writing or speaking.
Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English capitalization, punctuation, and spelling when writing.
Content: What is a central theme of “[Excerpt from] The Mozart Question ”? Use two details from the story to support your response.

SubTopics: Cite textual evidence to support analysis of what the text says explicitly as well as inferences drawn from the text.
Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English grammar and usage when writing or speaking.
Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English capitalization, punctuation, and spelling when writing.
Content: In “[Excerpt from] Leonardo da Vinci: Renaissance Genius,” why were Leonardo and the other apprentices required to complete chores like sweeping the floor and cleaning brushes? Use two details from the article to support your response.

SubTopics: Determine a central idea of a text and how it is conveyed through particular details; provide a summary of the text distinct from personal opinions or judgments.
Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English grammar and usage when writing or speaking.
Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English capitalization, punctuation, and spelling when writing.
Content: How do lines 24 through 38 help to develop a central idea of “[Excerpt from] Leonardo da Vinci: Renaissance Genius ”? Use two details from the article to support your response.

SubTopics: Determine the meaning of words and phrases as they are used in a text, including figurative, connotative, and technical meanings.
Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English grammar and usage when writing or speaking.
Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English capitalization, punctuation, and spelling when writing.
Content: Read this sentence from lines 44 and 45 of “[Excerpt from] Leonardo da Vinci for Kids: His Life and Ideas.”
:box:Leonardo learned there was more to art than holding a paintbrush.
What does the phrase “more to art than holding a paintbrush” mean? Use two details from the article to support your response.

Topics: Informational Text - Integration Of Knowledge & Ideas
SubTopics: Compare and contrast one author's presentation of events with that of another (e.g., a memoir written by and a biography on the same person).
Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English grammar and usage when writing or speaking.
Demonstrate command of the conventions of standard English capitalization, punctuation, and spelling when writing.
Use knowledge of language and its conventions when writing, speaking, reading, or listening.
Determine or clarify the meaning of unknown and multiple-meaning words and phrases based on grade 6 reading and content, choosing flexibly from a range of strategies.
Content: Both “[Excerpt from] Leonardo da Vinci: Renaissance Genius” and “[Excerpt from] Leonardo da Vinci for Kids: His Life and Ideas” describe Verrocchio's bottega. How are the descriptions different? Why was Verrocchio's bottega an important place for art and ideas in Florence? Use details from both articles to support your response.

:box:In your response, be sure to

• explain how the descriptions of Verrocchio's bottega in “[Excerpt from] Leonardo da Vinci: Renaissance Genius” and “[Excerpt from] Leonardo da Vinci for Kids: His Life and Ideas” are different
• explain why Verrocchio's bottega was an important place for art and ideas in Florence
• use details from both articles to support your response
